title: Esophageal Perforation (Boerhaave’s Syndrome)
diagnosis_topic: Transmural esophageal rupture following forceful emesis
setup_script: “A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath after repeated episodes of vomiting following a heavy meal. He has a history of alcoholism. On arrival, he appears toxic. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “BP 90/50 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 28/min, Temp 38.2 °C. Patient appears toxic.”
“He reports severe chest pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath, and painful swallowing after forceful retching. No prior history of reflux disease.”
“Exam reveals subcutaneous emphysema in the neck, mediastinal crepitus (Hamman’s crunch), and tachypnea.”
“WBC 18,000/µL, lactate elevated. Pleural fluid, if obtained, contains high amylase and food particles.”
“Pneumomediastinum and left pleural effusion are present with widened mediastinum.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests CT scan with IV and oral contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: “CT shows extravasation of oral contrast from the distal esophagus into the mediastinum with surrounding air and fluid collections.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates NPO status and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: “Broad-spectrum antibiotics are started. Patient remains tachycardic but blood pressure improves with fluids.”
“Thoracic surgery is consulted, and the patient is taken for operative repair.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis or treatment
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient deteriorates rapidly with worsening hypotension and hypoxemia. He progresses to septic shock and multiorgan failure.”
“Nonoperative management may be considered only for contained cervical perforations without systemic toxicity, with antibiotics and drainage.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with operative management
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient undergoes primary closure of the esophageal perforation with drainage of the mediastinum.”
“What surgical exposure would you use for a distal esophageal perforation?”

“Through a left thoracotomy, the distal esophagus is exposed, perforation identified, and primary repair with buttress reinforcement performed. Drains are placed in the mediastinum and pleural space.”
“Minimally invasive or laparotomy approaches may be considered depending on surgeon experience and location of perforation. The key principles remain adequate exposure, repair, and drainage.”
“Postoperatively, the patient remains NPO with jejunal feeding initiated. Chest tubes are managed, and serial imaging is planned to assess healing.”
“Patient is counseled on avoidance of alcohol and the importance of early medical attention for future severe vomiting episodes.”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of esophageal perforation based on history and physical exam
Use of appropriate imaging to confirm diagnosis and site of perforation
Early initiation of NPO status, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and surgical consultation
Selection between operative repair versus nonoperative management
Choice of surgical exposure and principles of esophageal repair
Postoperative management including nutrition, drainage, and infection control
